title: Atomic-Scale Insights into the High-Pressure Superconductor La3Ni2O7 and Topotactically Reduced LaNiO2 Single Crystals
content: Rare-earth nickel oxides, known for their intricate interplay between structure and properties, serve as a central foundation for the exploration of novel quantum phases and advanced applications. Recent topotactic transformations of perovskite nickelates have allowed precise control of oxygen vacancies, thereby exploiting the resulting coupling effects in these materials. The discovery of superconductivity in thin films of the infinite-layer (IL) nickelate Nd0.8Sr0.2NiO2 [1] has opened a new avenue to explore a material system closely related to cuprate high-temperature superconductors. To unravel the potential of these phenomena, it is imperative to gain in-depth insights into the atomic-scale lattice and electronic structure during topotactic reduction. Recently, the discovery of high-temperature superconductivity in La3Ni2O7 at high pressures (>14 GPa) has attracted considerable attention [2]. However, the fundamental properties of the superconducting phase are currently the subject of controversial debates, including the interpretation of the possible filamentary character, whereas early investigations consistently postulated a crystal structure consisting of NiO6 octahedral bilayers stacked along the c-axis on La3Ni2O7. Our atomic-scale investigations, detailed below, establish a critical link between the observable properties of nickelates and their underlying microscopic origins, paving the way for further exploration of nickelates with distinct crystal structures.
